pr_title: alts: Limit number of concurrent handshakes to 32

timeline.message: alts: Limit number of concurrent handshakes to 32

timeline.bodyText: Just curious, why we want to flush here?
timeline.author: jiangtaoli2016

replies.bodyText: Without the flush no data would be sent. Probably ever. Normally the flush is handled at a higher level: RPC senders will do the flush themselves, and we do a flush after each batch of reads (in case the reads triggered writes). Since the event triggering this code is not on the normal read and write paths, there wouldn't be a flush naturally occurring.
replies.author: ejona86

timeline.bodyText: Drive by comment: I'd suggest removing the "b/****" in the comment. :)
timeline.author: matthewstevenson88

replies.bodyText: Bug numbers and CL numbers are considered safe in OSS. We don't tend to use them because they aren't helpful to other readers, though. Since this is temporary until async TSI in Q1ish and the bug details are quite involved, it seemed fair.
replies.author: ejona86

timeline.bodyText:
Question, which of the following can be assumed if tsiHandshakeHandler.userEventTriggered() is called multiple times?

The argument ChannelHandlerContext ctx can be different instances.
The argument evt of ProtocolNegotiationEvent type can be different instances for a fixed ctx argument.
timeline.author: dapengzhang0

replies.bodyText:
The ctx argument should be the same every time. If not, it is generally a bug, since this is not a @ChannelHandler.Sharable handler.
There should only ever be one ProtocolNegotiationEvent for this handler instance, which provides this negotiator the results of the previous negotiator. If it happens more than once, then it would be a bug elsewhere.
replies.author: ejona86
